prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum imaging of ultrared starbursts in ADFS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum imaging of ultrared starbursts. Goal is to reach 100uJy/beam r.m.s. with a FWHM synthesised beamwidth of 0.14" (C36-5) in band 7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard continuum observations, and have set the spectral setup accordingly.

Our scientific objectives are possible only with the transformational capabilities offered by ALMA in C36-5: a resolution of 0.14 arcsec in band 7, corresponding to 1 kpc at z ~ 5 (largest structure reliably imaged, 2.2 arcsec, which exceeds even the largest SMG sizes seen in CO J=1-0, see Ivison et al. 2011).

We base our sensitivity requirements on the worst-case scenario wherein the lowest plausible band-7 flux density (15mJy, as measured already by SCUBA2 or LABOCA) is diluted across 30x 0.12-arcsec beams. To map such emission at >=5 sigma requires a noise level of 100 uJy/beam, which takes 5 min per target.
Fig. 3 shows how we have used CASA to simulate observations in configuration C36-5 of a particularly demanding target that comprises all of: 1) an exponential face-on disk, with 0.75" FWHM and 2) an unresolved AGN and 3) an edge-on disk, 1.18" x 0.24" FWHM. The total band-7 flux density, 15mJy (the minimum we can see) is divided equally between the three components. Fig. 3 shows that the uv coverage and sensitivity obtained for 5 min of integration is sufficient to recover the structure and flux, even for the unusually demanding scenario simulated here.
Including OT-predicted overheads, this science goal will take a total of 44 mins.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We have defined a large sample of galaxies that are both faint (ergo unlensed - in this regime we cannot afford the vagaries of galaxy-galaxy lens model reconstruction) and extremely red (ergo very distant). We further refined our sample via SCUBA-2 imaging and ALMA spectral scans, rejecting z<4 interlopers. The remaining galaxies represent the most intense starbursts in the z>4 Universe - the precursors of galaxies on the red sequence.
Our goal here is to directly characterise the physical scale and morphology of the dust in the 30 faintest and reddest of these z>4 starbursts - the first time a significant sample of such distant systems has been imaged interferometrically. Is the physical distribution of the dust best modelled as a compact, optically thick disk, as with local ULIRGs, or by a more extended optically thin disk, like local spirals? Is the Schmidt-Kennicutt law different in such young galaxies? What drives these early starbursts - major mergers, or the steady accretion of gas onto a disk, or perhaps something unexpected?
Via the relatively simple observations proposed here, ALMA will reveal the manner in which the ancestors of todays massive galaxies were formed.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is the re-submission of 2013.1.00001.S. We have been informed that one of the science goals has no chance of being observed due to the array schedule; others may also miss out. Any sources observed successfully in Cycle 2 will not be re-observed.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
